{{About|the 2014 film|other uses|Into the Woods (disambiguation)}} {{distinguish|Into the Forest}} {{Use mdy dates|date=June 2014}} {{Infobox film | name = Into the Woods | image = Into the Woods film poster.jpg | alt = A witch ominously peering through a thicket of branches. | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Rob Marshall]] | producer = Rob Marshall
John DeLuca
[[Marc E. Platt|Marc Platt]]
Callum McDougall | screenplay = [[James Lapine]] | based on = {{Based on|''[[Into the Woods]]''|[[Stephen Sondheim]]
James Lapine}} | starring = [[Meryl Streep]]
[[Emily Blunt]]
[[James Corden]]
[[Anna Kendrick]]
[[Chris Pine]]
[[Tracey Ullman]]
[[Christine Baranski]]
[[Johnny Depp]] | narrator = James Corden | music = Stephen Sondheim | cinematography = [[Dion Beebe]] | editing = Wyatt Smith | studio = [[Walt Disney Pictures]]
Lucamar Productions
Marc Platt Productions | distributor = [[Walt Disney Studios Motion Pictures|Walt Disney Studios
Motion Pictures]] | released = {{Film date|2014|12|08|[[Ziegfeld Theatre (1969)|Ziegfeld Theatre]]|2014|12|25|United States}} | runtime = 124 minutes{{cite web | url=http://www.bbfc.co.uk/releases/woods-film | title=''INTO THE WOODS'' (PG) | work=[[British Board of Film Classification]] | date=November 11, 2014 | accessdate=November 11, 2014}} | country = United States | language = English | budget = $50 million | gross = $213.1 million{{cite web |url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?page=main&id=intothewoods.htm |title=Into the Woods | website=[[Box Office Mojo]] | accessdate=November 28, 2015}} }} '''''Into the Woods''''' is a 2014 American [[Musical film|musical]] [[fantasy film]] directed by [[Rob Marshall]], and [[Film adaptation|adapted to the screen]] by [[James Lapine]] from his and [[Stephen Sondheim]]'s [[Into the Woods|1986 Broadway musical of the same name]].{{cite news|last=Ng|first=David|title=Sam Mendes, Rob Marshall will revive their revival of 'Cabaret{{'-}} |url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/arts/culture/la-et-cm-sam-mendes-rob-marshall-cabaret-20130905,0,7675194.story |accessdate=September 5, 2013|newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=September 5, 2013}} A [[Walt Disney Pictures]] production, it features an [[ensemble cast]] that includes [[Meryl Streep]], [[Emily Blunt]], [[James Corden]], [[Anna Kendrick]], [[Chris Pine]], [[Tracey Ullman]], [[Christine Baranski]], [[Lilla Crawford]], [[Daniel Huttlestone]], [[MacKenzie Mauzy]], [[Billy Magnussen]], and [[Johnny Depp]]. Inspired by the [[Brothers Grimm|Grimm Brothers]]' fairy tales of "[[Little Red Riding Hood]]", "[[Cinderella]]", "[[Jack and the Beanstalk]]", and "[[Rapunzel]]", the film is a [[fantasy genre]] centered on a childless couple, who set out to end a curse placed on them by a vengeful witch. Ultimately, the characters are forced to rectify the consequences of their actions.{{cite news|last=Kit|first=Borys|author2=Tatiana Siegel|title=Chris Pine, Jake Gyllenhaal Circling Musical 'Into the Woods' (Exclusive)|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/heat-vision/chris-pine-jake-gyllenhaal-circling-522404|accessdate=September 5, 2013|newspaper=The Hollywood Reporter|date=May 14, 2013}} After several unsuccessful attempts by other studios and producers to adapt the musical to film, Disney announced in 2012 that it was producing an adaptation, with Marshall directing and John DeLuca serving as producer. [[Principal photography]] commenced in September 2013, and took place entirely in the [[United Kingdom]], including at [[Shepperton Studios]] in [[London]]. ''Into the Woods'' held its [[Premiere|world premiere]] at the [[Ziegfeld Theatre (1969)|Ziegfeld Theatre]] in [[New York City]] on December 8, 2014, and was released theatrically in the United States on December 25, 2014.{{cite news|last=Schillaci|first=Sophie|title=Disney Dates Musical 'Into the Woods' Opposite 'Annie' in December 2014|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/disney-dates-musical-woods-opposite-568528|accessdate=September 5, 2013|newspaper=The Hollywood Reporter|date=June 13, 2013|author2=Pamela McClintock}} The film was commercially successful and received generally positive reviews, receiving praise for its acting performances, visual style, and production merits, but received criticism for its lighter tone compared to the source material and the changes made for the film translation. It grossed $213 million worldwide.{{cite news|last1=Piccalo|first1=Gina|title=Record-breaking 'Into the Woods' is a surprise hit|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/movies/la-et-mn-into-the-woods-20150106-story.html|accessdate=January 9, 2015|work=Los Angeles Times|date=January 5, 2015}} ''Into the Woods'' received three [[Academy Award]] nominations at the [[87th Academy Awards]], including a [[Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress|Best Supporting Actress]] nomination for Streep, and three [[Golden Globe Award]] nominations at the [[72nd Golden Globe Awards]], including [[Golden Globe Award for Best Motion Picture – Musical or Comedy|Best Motion Picture – Musical or Comedy]]. ==Plot== A baker ([[James Corden]]) and his wife ([[Emily Blunt]]) wish for a child but suffer under a curse laid upon the baker's family by a [[Witchcraft|Witch]] ([[Meryl Streep]]) who found the baker's father robbing her garden when his mother was pregnant. Because the baker's father also stole some magic beans, the witch's own mother cursed her to be ugly. The witch is able to lift the curse and allow them to have a child, but only if the baker and his wife obtain four critical items for her to make a potion: a white cow, a red cape, a yellow strand of hair, and a golden slipper, none of which she is allowed to touch. The witch's demands eventually bring the baker and his wife into contact with Jack ([[Daniel Huttlestone]]), who is selling his beloved cow, Milky-White, and to whom the baker offers magic beans left him by his father (which were stolen from the witch) which grow into a large beanstalk; with Red Riding Hood ([[Lilla Crawford]]), whose red cape the couple noticed when she stopped by the bakery earlier to buy bread and sweets on her way to grandmother's house; with blonde-haired Rapunzel ([[MacKenzie Mauzy]]), whose tower the baker's wife passes in the woods; and with Cinderella ([[Anna Kendrick]]), who also runs into the baker's wife while fleeing from the pursuing prince ([[Chris Pine]]) and whose ball outfit includes gold slippers. After a series of failed attempts and misadventures, the baker and his wife are finally able to gather the items necessary to break the spell. Meanwhile, each of the other characters receives a "[[happy ending]]": Cinderella marries the prince; Rapunzel is freed from her guardian, the witch, by Cinderella's prince's brother and marries him; Jack provides for his mother by stealing riches from the [[Giant]] in the sky, and kills the pursuing giant by cutting down the beanstalk; Little Red Riding Hood and her grandmother are saved from the [[Big Bad Wolf]] ([[Johnny Depp]]); and the witch regains her youth and beauty after drinking the potion. However, each of the characters learns that their endings don't remain happy: the baker is worried that he is a poor father to his newborn baby; the baker's wife is temporarily seduced by the prince; Cinderella is disenchanted by her cheating prince; and the witch learns that she has lost her magic powers. The growth of a second beanstalk from the last remaining magic bean allows the giant's wife to climb down and threaten the kingdom and its inhabitants if they do not deliver Jack in retribution for killing her husband. The characters attempt to find Jack, but debate the morality of handing Jack over. In the process, Red Riding Hood's mother and grandmother, Jack's mother, and the baker's wife are killed. The characters blame each other for their individual actions that led to the tragedy, ultimately blaming the witch for growing the beans in the first place. She curses them for their inability to accept responsibility for their individual actions. Casting all the remaining beans away, the witch begs her mother to punish her again, hoping to regain her powers, but instead she disappears into a large pit of boiling tar. The remaining characters resolve to kill the threatening giant's wife though Cinderella and the baker try to explain to the distraught Red Riding Hood and Jack the complicated morality of retribution and revenge. The characters lure the giant's wife into stepping in the tar pit where she ultimately trips and falls to her death. With the giant's wife dead, the characters move forward with their ruined lives. The baker, thinking of his wife, is determined to be a good father. Cinderella decides to leave the prince and help the baker, and Jack and Red Riding Hood, now orphans, are living with the baker and Cinderella. The baker comforts his son after he begins to cry by telling the story of the film as the movie ends with the witch's moral, meaning that children can change due to the parent's actions and behaviors. ==Cast== {{div col}} * [[Meryl Streep]] as The Witch{{cite news|last=Yamato|first=Jen|title=Tony-Nominated Tammy Blanchard Headed 'Into The Woods'|url=http://www.deadline.com/2013/07/tammy-blanchard-disney-into-the-woods/|accessdate=September 5, 2013|newspaper=Deadline Hollywood|date=July 23, 2013}} * [[Emily Blunt]] as The Baker's Wife{{cite news|last=Finke|first=Nikki|title=Johnny Depp And Meryl Streep "Deals Almost Wrapped" For 'Into The Woods' Movie|url=http://www.deadline.com/2013/04/johnny-depp-and-meryl-streep-deals-almost-wrapped-for-into-the-woods-movie/|accessdate=September 5, 2013|newspaper=Deadline Hollywood|date=April 26, 2013}} * [[James Corden]] as The Baker{{cite news|last=Abramovitch|first=Seth|title=Broadway Star Joins Johnny Depp in 'Into the Woods'|url=http://www.broadwayworld.com/article/James-Corden-Joins-Streep-Depp-In-INTO-THE-WOODS-Movie-20130510|accessdate=November 25, 2013|newspaper=Broadway World|date=May 10, 2013}} * [[Anna Kendrick]] as [[Cinderella]]{{cite news|last=Kit|first=Borys|title=Anna Kendrick in Talks to Play Cinderella in Disney's 'Into the Woods'|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/anna-kendrick-talks-play-cinderella-573423|accessdate=September 5, 2013|newspaper=The Hollywood Reporter|date=June 21, 2013}} * [[Chris Pine]] as [[Cinderella|Cinderella's Prince]] * [[Tracey Ullman]] as Jack's Mother{{cite news|last=Kit|first=Borys|title=Tracey Ullman in Talks to Join Disney's 'Into the Woods' (Exclusive)|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/heat-vision/tracey-ullman-talks-join-disneys-567666|accessdate=September 5, 2013|newspaper=The Hollywood Reporter|date=June 12, 2013}} * [[Christine Baranski]] as [[Stepfamily#Fairy tales|Cinderella's Stepmother]]{{cite news|last=Sneider|first=Jeff|title='The Good Wife' Star Christine Baranski to Reteam With 'Chicago' Director on Disney's 'Into the Woods' (Exclusive)|url=http://www.thewrap.com/movies/column-post/good-wife-star-christine-baranski-reteam-chicago-director-disneys-woods-92186|accessdate=September 5, 2013|newspaper=The Wrap|date=May 16, 2013}} * [[Johnny Depp]] as [[Big Bad Wolf|The Big Bad Wolf]]{{cite news|last=Siegel|first=Tatiana|title=Johnny Depp to Star in Disney Musical 'Into the Woods'|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/johnny-depp-star-disney-musical-447361|accessdate=September 5, 2013|newspaper=The Hollywood Reporter|date=April 26, 2013|author2=Borys Kit}} * [[Lilla Crawford]] as [[Little Red Riding Hood]]{{cite news|title=Annie's Lilla Crawford Will Be Little Red in Into the Woods Film, Featuring New Song by Stephen Sondheim|url=http://www.playbill.com/article/annies-lilla-crawford-will-be-little-red-in-into-the-woods-film-featuring-new-song-by-stephen-sondheim-com-209549|accessdate=September 16, 2013|newspaper=Playbill|date=August 12, 2018}} * [[Daniel Huttlestone]] as [[Jack and the Beanstalk|Jack]]{{cite news|last=Fleming Jr.|first=Mike|title=Daniel Huttlestone Goes From 'Les Mis' To 'Into The Woods'|url=http://www.deadline.com/2013/06/daniel-huttlestone-goes-from-les-mis-to-into-the-woods/|accessdate=September 5, 2013|newspaper=Deadline Hollywood|date=June 21, 2013}} * [[MacKenzie Mauzy]] as [[Rapunzel]]{{cite news|title='Into The Woods' Casts Its Rapunzel|url=http://www.deadline.com/2013/07/into-the-woods-casts-its-rapunzel/|accessdate=September 5, 2013|newspaper=Deadline Hollywood|date=July 24, 2013}} * [[Billy Magnussen]] as [[Rapunzel|Rapunzel's Prince]]{{cite news|last=Fleming Jr.|first=Mike|title=Billy Magnussen Ventures 'Into The Woods' To Replace Jake Gyllenhaal|url=http://www.deadline.com/2013/07/billy-magnussen-ventures-into-the-woods-to-replace-jake-gyllenhaal/|accessdate=September 5, 2013|newspaper=Deadline Hollywood|date=July 22, 2013}} * [[Tammy Blanchard]] as Florinda * [[Lucy Punch]] as Lucinda * [[Frances de la Tour]] as the [[Giant]]'s Wife * Richard Glover as the [[Steward (office)|Steward]] * [[Joanna Riding]] as [[Fairy godmother|Cinderella's Mother]] * [[Annette Crosbie]] as Little Red Riding Hood's Grandmother{{cite news|title=Production Begins on Disney's Musical INTO THE WOODS Starring Meryl Streep, Emily Blunt, Johnny Depp, Chris Pine, and Anna Kendrick|url=http://collider.com/into-the-woods-movie-filming-johnny-depp/|accessdate=September 16, 2013|newspaper=Collider|date=September 16, 2013}} * [[Simon Russell Beale]] as the Baker's Father * Tug as Milky-White{{cite web|title=Into the Woods: Press Kit|url=http://www.wdsmediafile.com/media/IntoTheWoods/writen-material/IntoTheWoods5491d6189e646.pdf|publisher=The Walt Disney Studios|accessdate=June 21, 2015}} {{div col end}} ==Stage-to-screen changes== While it was initially reported that Disney had decided to make some major plot changes for the film version in order to make it more family friendly,{{cite news|last1=Hetrick |first1=Adam |last2=Gioia |first2=Michael |title=Sondheim Reveals Plot Changes for Disney Into the Woods Film |url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/192526-Sondheim-Reveals-Plot-Changes-for-Disney-Into-the-Woods-Film |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140619000909/http://playbill.com/news/article/192526-Sondheim-Reveals-Plot-Changes-for-Disney-Into-the-Woods-Film |dead-url=yes |archive-date=June 19, 2014 |accessdate=June 19, 2014 |newspaper=Playbill |date=June 18, 2014 }} [[Stephen Sondheim]] revealed that this was not the case and that any changes in the film version had been approved by him and James Lapine.{{cite news|url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/192718-Sondheim-Issues-Response-Following-Report-of-Disney-Into-the-Woods-Film-Changes|title=Sondheim Issues Response Following Report of Disney Into the Woods Film Changes|work=Playbill|date=June 23, 2014|accessdate=June 23, 2014|last1=Hetrick|first1=Adam}}{{cite news|url=http://insidemovies.ew.com/2014/06/23/stephen-sondheim-statement-into-the-woods/|title=Stephen Sondheim releases statement after backlash over 'Into the Woods' comments|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|date=June 23, 2014|accessdate=June 23, 2014|last1=Hetrick|first1=Adam}} Thus the film does slightly differ from the stage production. The songs "I Guess This Is Goodbye",{{cite news|last1=Watkins|first1=Gwynne|title='Into the Woods': How the Movie Differs from the Stage Musical|url=https://www.yahoo.com/movies/into-the-woods-changes-104846985787.html|accessdate=January 21, 2015|work=[[Yahoo! Movies]]|publisher=[[Yahoo! Inc]]|date=December 10, 2014}} "Maybe They're Magic",{{cite news|author1=Michael Gioia|author2=Adam Hetrick|author3=Carey Purcell|title=Star-Studded "Into the Woods" Film Brings in $140 Million Worldwide|url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/star-studded-into-the-woods-film-brings-in-140-million-worldwide-339569/print|accessdate=January 21, 2015|work=[[Playbill]]|date=January 19, 2015|quote=The big-screen adaptation welcomes songs from the stage musical, including "Children Will Listen," "Giants in the Sky," "On the Steps of the Palace," "No One Is Alone" and "Agony," among others. The film cuts songs such as "I Guess This Is Goodbye/Maybe They're Magic," "Ever After" and "No More," among others.}} "First Midnight" and "Second Midnight" interludes, "Ever After" (Act I finale of the original play), "So Happy",{{cite news|last1=Stevens|first1=Dana|title=Into the Woods: Great cast. Great score. So why is Rob Marshall's adaptation so lost in the woods?|url=http://www.slate.com/articles/arts/movies/2014/12/into_the_woods_starring_meryl_streep_and_emily_blunt_reviewed.html|accessdate=January 21, 2015|work=[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]|publisher=The Slate Group LLC.|date=December 24, 2014}} "Into the Woods" Reprise, "Agony" Reprise and "No More" (performed by the baker) were cut from the film,{{cite news|last1=Rosenberg|first1=Alyssa|title=How Disney wrecked "Into The Woods"|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/act-four/wp/2014/12/26/how-disney-wrecked-into-the-woods/|accessdate=January 21, 2015|work=[[The Washington Post]]|date=December 26, 2014}} although both "Ever After" and "No More" are used as instrumentals in the film. Meanwhile, many of the songs in the film have slightly different lyrics than their stage counterparts due to the slight tweaking of story lines. Other changes include a major reduction of the significant role of the "mysterious man", who manipulates much of the action in the first act and is eventually revealed to be the baker's father. Also, the character of the narrator is deleted, and the film is instead narrated by the baker.{{cite news|last1=Whyte|first1=Marama|title=Five 'Into the Woods' stage-to-screen changes|url=http://www.hypable.com/2014/12/24/into-the-woods-stage-to-screen-changes/|accessdate=January 2, 2015|work=Hypable.com|date=December 24, 2014}} The minor role of Cinderella's father was cut, and he is instead mentioned as deceased. Due to the film's compressed story line, Rapunzel's pregnancy is eliminated, as is the subplot where the two princes have affairs with [[Snow White]] and [[Sleeping Beauty]]. In the film, the giant's wife attacks during the marriages of Cinderella and Rapunzel to their respective princes, no more than a few weeks after the events of act one; in the stage show, nearly a year passes between the first and second acts. Rapunzel's ultimate fate is also changed: rather than being killed by the giant, she refuses to cooperate with the witch and flees with her prince. Similarly, much of the violence and sexual content is slightly toned down from the original musical. For instance, the death of Jack's mother is less violent in the film. On stage, the steward clubs her to death with his staff; in the film, he simply shoves her to the ground and she hits her head on a log. The death of the baker's wife is not explicitly shown in the film, and the cause of her death is changed from being crushed by a tree in the giant's wife's wake to accidentally backing off the edge of a cliff while fleeing from the wife of the giant. ==Production== ===Early development=== Early attempts of adapting ''Into the Woods'' to film occurred in the early 1990s, with a script written by [[Lowell Ganz]] and [[Babaloo Mandel]]. A reading was held with a cast that included [[Robin Williams]] as the Baker, [[Goldie Hawn]] as the Baker's Wife, [[Cher]] as the Witch, [[Danny DeVito]] as the Giant, [[Steve Martin]] as the Wolf, and [[Roseanne Barr]] as Jack's Mother.{{cite web|last=Cerasaro|first=Pat|title=BWW EXCLUSIVE: Stephen Sondheim Talks Past, Present & Future|url=http://www.broadwayworld.com/article/BWW-EXCLUSIVE-Stephen-Sondheim-Talks-Past-Present-Future-20101103-page2|publisher=BroadwayWorld.com|accessdate=September 5, 2013|date=November 3, 2010}} By 1991, [[Columbia Pictures]] and [[Jim Henson Productions]] were also developing a film adaptation with [[Craig Zadan]] as producer and [[Rob Minkoff]] as director.{{cite news|last=Willman|first=David|title=Jim Henson's Children Put Together a String of Big Deals to Keep Alive : The Muppet Legacy|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1992-07-26/business/fi-5359_1_jim-henson/3|accessdate=September 5, 2013|newspaper=The Los Angeles Times|date=July 26, 1992|pages=3 of 3}}{{cite news|title=Movie To Mix Live Actors, Jim Henson Characters|url=http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/1991-09-30/features/9102080788_1_brian-henson-film-project-jim-henson-productions|accessdate=September 5, 2013|newspaper=The New York Times|date=September 30, 1991}} In 1997, Columbia put the film into [[Turnaround (filmmaking)|turnaround]], with Minkoff still attached as director, and [[Billy Crystal]], [[Meg Ryan]], and [[Susan Sarandon]] reportedly in talks to star.{{cite news|last=Fleming|first=Michael|title='Bliss' sticks in ratings mire; Col chops 'Woods'|url=https://variety.com/1997/voices/columns/bliss-sticks-in-ratings-mire-col-chops-woods-1117433140/|accessdate=September 5, 2013|newspaper=Variety|date=January 22, 1997}} After the report by [[Variety (magazine)|''Variety'']], a film adaptation of ''Into the Woods'' remained inactive for 15 years. ===Development at Disney=== After the critical and commercial success of ''[[Chicago (2002 film)|Chicago]]'' in 2002, director [[Rob Marshall]] approached [[Stephen Sondheim]] as he was interested in adapting one of his musicals such as ''[[Follies]]'' and ''[[Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street]]'', although Sondheim suggested ''Into the Woods'' instead.{{cite news|last1=Abramovitch|first1=Seth|title=Perverted Wolves, Cheating Wives and a Fired 10-Year-Old: The Dark Path to Disney's 'Into the Woods'|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/perverted-wolves-cheating-wives-a-755359|accessdate=December 13, 2014|work=The Hollywood Reporter|publisher=Prometheus Global Media|date=December 10, 2014}} Marshall concurred, but development of the project was then postponed while he focused on directing ''[[Memoirs of a Geisha (film)|Memoirs of a Geisha]]'' and ''[[Nine (2009 live-action film)|Nine]]''. In 2011, Marshall's interest in the project was rekindled when he heard a speech by President [[Barack Obama]] on the tenth anniversary of the [[September 11th attacks]] to the families of the 9/11 victims, which seemed to evoke the same message as the musical's most important song, "No One Is Alone".{{cite news|last1=Feinberg|first1=Scott|title=Rob Marshall on Movie Musicals and His Journey 'Into the Woods' (Q&A)|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/race/rob-marshall-movie-musicals-his-760996|accessdate=January 7, 2015|work=The Hollywood Reporter|publisher=Prometheus Global Media|date=January 5, 2015}} Marshall firmly believed that ''Into the Woods'' was “a fairy tale for the post-9/11 generation".{{cite news|last1=Gray|first1=Tim|title=Disney's 'Into the Woods' Enters Awards Season on High Note|url=https://variety.com/2014/film/news/disney-enters-awards-race-with-into-the-woods-1201362874/|accessdate=December 13, 2014|work=Variety|date=November 22, 2014}} In January 2012, Marshall approached [[Walt Disney Pictures]]—for whom he had just directed ''[[Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides]]''—and pitched the idea to the studio, with Lapine writing the script and Sondheim "expected" to write new songs.{{cite news|title=Disney Sets Rob Marshall To Direct Adaptation Of 'Into The Woods'|url=http://www.deadline.com/2012/01/disney-sets-rob-marshall-to-direct-adapation-of-into-the-woods/|accessdate=September 5, 2013|newspaper=Deadline Hollywood|date=January 11, 2012}} [[Academy Award]]-winner [[Dion Beebe]], who previously collaborated with Marshall on ''Chicago'', ''Memoirs of a Geisha'', and ''Nine'', served as cinematographer.{{cite news|last=Giardina|first=Carolyn|title=Honors and Hires: Oscar Winning DP Dion Beebe Goes 'Into the Woods'|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/behind-screen/honors-hires-oscar-winning-dp-564344|accessdate=September 5, 2013|newspaper=The Hollywood Reporter|date=June 7, 2013}} Sondheim confirmed that a new song had been written for the film.{{cite news|last=Wolf|first=Matt|title=Stephen Sondheim: An audience with a theatre legend|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/theatre-dance/features/stephen-sondheim-an-audience-with-a-theatre-legend-8559902.html|accessdate=September 5, 2013|newspaper=The Independent|date=April 5, 2013}} With Disney's backing, a three-day reading of the entire updated screenplay took place in New York in October 2012 under Marshall's direction, with [[Nina Arianda]] as the Baker's Wife, [[Victoria Clark]] as Cinderella's Mother/Granny/Giant, [[James Corden]] as the Baker, [[Donna Murphy]] as the Witch, [[Christine Baranski]] as Cinderella's Stepmother, [[Tammy Blanchard]] as Florinda, Ivan Hernandez as the Wolf, [[Megan Hilty]] as Lucinda, [[Cheyenne Jackson]] as Rapunzel's Prince, [[Allison Janney]] as Jack's Mother, [[Anna Kendrick]] as Cinderella, [[Michael McGrath (actor)|Michael McGrath]] as Steward/Mysterious Man, [[Laura Osnes]] as Rapunzel, [[Taylor Trensch]] as Jack, Casey Whyland as Little Red Riding Hood, and [[Patrick Wilson (American actor)|Patrick Wilson]] as Cinderella's Prince.{{cite news|last=Hetrick|first=Adam|title=Nina Arianda, Victoria Clark, Patrick Wilson, Cheyenne Jackson, James Corden Part of Into the Woods Film Reading|url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/170672-Nina-Arianda-Victoria-Clark-Patrick-Wilson-Cheyenne-Jackson-James-Corden-Part-of-Into-the-Woods-Film-Reading|accessdate=September 5, 2013|newspaper=Playbill|date=October 2, 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131103054115/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/170672-Nina-Arianda-Victoria-Clark-Patrick-Wilson-Cheyenne-Jackson-James-Corden-Part-of-Into-the-Woods-Film-Reading|archive-date=November 3, 2013|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} It was this reading which ultimately convinced [[The Walt Disney Studios (division)|Walt Disney Studios]] president [[Sean Bailey]] to [[green-light]] the film despite ongoing concerns about the dark nature of the original musical (which Disney executives had begun to understand since Marshall's original pitch). However, Disney (which self-finances all its films){{cite news|last1=Block|first1=Alex Ben|title=Disney CFO Outlines Strategy, Explains Forgoing Third Party Financing|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/disney-cfo-outlines-strategy-explains-761468|accessdate=January 9, 2015|issue=The Hollywood Reporter|publisher=Prometheus Global Media|date=January 6, 2015}} provided only a relatively small production budget of $50 million (relative to other feature-length fantasy films on its development slate), in turn forcing both cast and crew to accept pay cuts to work on the film. Reports subsequently surfaced in January 2013 that [[Meryl Streep]] had been cast to play the Witch.{{cite news|last=Boughton|first=Kathryn|title=Roxbury Composer's Future: New Town, Working with Meryl Streep as a Witch|url=http://www.countytimes.com/articles/2013/01/31/entertainment/doc510959d3e6ffa160222903.txt|accessdate=September 5, 2013|newspaper=Litchfield County Times|date=January 31, 2013|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130215182723/http://www.countytimes.com/articles/2013/01/31/entertainment/doc510959d3e6ffa160222903.txt|archive-date=February 15, 2013|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}}{{cite web|title=Meryl Streep Will Head Into The Woods With Rob Marshall|url=http://www.cinemablend.com/new/Meryl-Streep-Head-Woods-With-Rob-Marshall-35460.html|publisher=Cinema Blend|last=Puchko|first=Kristy|accessdate=February 1, 2013}} Streep had instituted a personal "no witch" rule after she turned 40 and was offered three witch roles, but ultimately broke her own rule to do a Sondheim role again. (As a young [[Yale University]] student, she had participated in the original production of Sondheim's ''[[The Frogs (musical)|The Frogs]]''.) During the same month, it was reported that Janney had been confirmed to join the film as well.{{cite web|url=http://www.cinemablend.com/television/West-Wing-Allison-Janney-Play-Anna-Faris-Mom-Chuck-Lorre-Comedy-Pilot-51915.html |title=The West Wing's Allison Janney To Play Anna Faris' Mom In Chuck Lorre's Comedy Pilot | quote = She was also recently cast in the fairy-tale fantasy movie Into the Woods which is also rumored to have Meryl Streep on board.|last=Kasperowicz|first=Leslie|accessdate=January 31, 2013}} Five months later, however, [[Tracey Ullman]] was cast as Jack's Mother instead. [[File:Into the Woods - Rapunzel's Tower under construction.jpg|thumb|Rapunzel's tower under construction at [[Waverley Abbey]] in [[Farnham]], Surrey.]] In April 2013, [[Johnny Depp]] was in final negotiations, along with Streep, to join the film. ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'' reported that to help make the film on such a tight budget, Depp agreed as a favor to Disney and to Marshall (whom he had just worked with in ''On Stranger Tides'') to a "boarding" arrangement, in which he would appear in a minor role for a fee of $1 million, instead of his typical fee of $20 million for a starring role.{{cite news|last1=Siegel|first1=Tatiana|title=How Johnny Depp Made $1 Million in a Week|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/how-johnny-depp-made-1-676799|accessdate=January 11, 2015|work=The Hollywood Reporter|publisher=Prometheus Global Media|date=February 6, 2014}} In May, James Corden, who took part in the reading of the screenplay, was in talks to play the role of the Baker.{{cite news|last=Hetrick|first=Adam|title=One Man, Two Guvnors Star James Corden in Talks for Into the Woods Film Adaptation|url=http://playbill.com/news/article/177569-One-Man-Two-Guvnors-Star-James-Corden-in-Talks-for-Into-the-Woods-Film-Adaptation|accessdate=September 5, 2013|newspaper=Playbill|date=May 3, 2013}} On May 10, 2013, Disney confirmed the casting of Streep, Depp, and Corden as the Witch, the Big Bad Wolf, and the Baker, respectively. That same month, [[Emily Blunt]] and [[Christine Baranski]] were cast, respectively, as the Baker's Wife and Cinderella's Stepmother.{{cite news|last=Abramovitch|first=Seth|title=Emily Blunt Circling Disney's 'Into the Woods'|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/emily-blunt-circling-disneys-woods-524132|accessdate=September 5, 2013|newspaper=The Hollywood Reporter|date=May 16, 2013}}{{cite news|last=Vineyard|first=Jennifer|title=Emily Blunt to Sing Better in Into the Woods Than She Did in That Karaoke Video|url=http://www.vulture.com/2013/06/emily-blunt-cant-live-down-that-karaoke-video.html|accessdate=September 5, 2013|newspaper=Vulture|date=June 5, 2013}} Marshall later confirmed that Blunt was selected for her "warm[th]" and likeability to ensure the emotional impact of the sudden death of the Baker's Wife: "[T]hat's very important for that character because it's the heart of the piece and you really have to love her so when she's gone it should feel like a kick in the gut." After she was cast, Blunt discovered she was pregnant and her costume and choreography had to be adjusted accordingly.{{cite news|last1=Gioia|first1=Michael|title=Emily Blunt On Hiding Her Real-Life Baby Bump, Vocal Nerves and the Much-Talked-About "Moment" in the "Woods"|url=http://playbill.com/news/article/emily-blunt-on-hiding-her-real-life-baby-bump-vocal-nerves-and-the-much-talked-about-moment-in-the-woods-336500|accessdate=January 11, 2015|work=Playbill.com|publisher=Playbill, Inc.|date=December 2, 2014}} However, her "overweight" appearance during production actually fit in with the role of the Baker's Wife; as she explained, "I feel like she would have eaten a lot of carbs working in the bakery." Also in May, [[Jake Gyllenhaal]] and [[Chris Pine]] entered negotiations to play the Princes.{{cite news|last=Busis|first=Hillary|title=Two princes kneel before you: Jake Gyllenhaal, Chris Pine in talks to join 'Into the Woods'|url=http://insidemovies.ew.com/2013/05/15/jake-gyllenhaal-chris-pine-into-the-woods/|accessdate=September 5, 2013|newspaper=Entertainment Weekly|date=May 15, 2013}} However, Gyllenhaal dropped out of the film due to scheduling conflicts with another film, ''[[Nightcrawler (film)|Nightcrawler]]'', and was subsequently replaced by [[Billy Magnussen]].{{cite news|last=Snieder|first=Jeff|title=Jake Gyllenhaal Exits 'Into the Woods' as 'Nightcrawler' Gets Greenlight (Exclusive)|url=http://www.thewrap.com/movies/column-post/jake-gyllenhaal-falls-out-woods-nightcrawler-gets-greenlight-exclusive-104076|accessdate=September 5, 2013|newspaper=The Wrap|date=July 17, 2013}} One month later, Anna Kendrick began talks to play Cinderella in the film. In June 2013, [[Walt Disney Studios (division)|Walt Disney Studios]] publicly announced that the film had been greenlighted, and scheduled a release date for Christmas Day 2014.{{cite news|last=Rome|first=Emily|title=Inside Movies 'Muppets' sequel gets new title, 'Into the Woods' gets release date, and more Disney updates|url=http://insidemovies.ew.com/2013/06/13/disney-updates-muppets-into-the-woods-tomorrowland/|accessdate=September 5, 2013|newspaper=Entertainment Weekly|date=June 13, 2013}} In July, [[MacKenzie Mauzy]], [[Tammy Blanchard]], [[Lucy Punch]] and [[Daniel Huttlestone]] joined the cast. In early August, [[The Ellen DeGeneres Show#Sophia Grace and Rosie|Sophia Grace Brownlee]]'s representatives announced that she had been cast as Little Red Riding Hood.{{cite news|last=Hetrick|first=Adam|title=Updated: YouTube Personality Sophia Grace Brownlee Confirmed for "Into the Woods" Film|url=http://playbill.com/news/article/180874-Updated-YouTube-Personality-Sophia-Grace-Brownlee-Confirmed-for-Into-the-Woods-Film|accessdate=September 5, 2013|newspaper=Playbill|date=August 7, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130810010729/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/180874-Updated-YouTube-Personality-Sophia-Grace-Brownlee-Confirmed-for-Into-the-Woods-Film|archive-date=August 10, 2013|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}}{{cite web | url=https://twitter.com/LucasBrownlee14 | title= Twitter feed of Lucas Brownlee: "Its official, @PrincessSGB (sophia grace brownlee) has landed the part of little red riding hood in the disney movie in to the wood,"| date=August 6, 2013 | accessdate=November 2, 2016 }} The announcement of Brownlee's casting, which was widely reported but never confirmed by Disney, was criticized as "a stunt" and was met with concern due to her age and the sexual undertones present between Little Red and the Wolf.{{cite news|last=Zuckerman|first=Esther|title=Sophia Grace Is Everything That's Wrong with the 'Into The Woods' Movie|url=http://www.theatlanticwire.com/entertainment/2013/08/sophia-grace-everything-s-wrong-woods-movie/68104/|newspaper=The Atlantic Wire|date=August 7, 2013| accessdate=November 2, 2016}}{{cite news|last=Lyons|first=Margaret|title=Internet Child Sophia Grace Cast in Into the Woods|url=http://www.vulture.com/2013/08/sophia-grace-cast-in-into-the-woods.html|accessdate=September 5, 2013|newspaper=Vulture|date=August 8, 2013|quote=Typically Little Red is a bit older than 10, given that the character experiences a sexual awakening—at the menacing and kind of rape-y hands of The (Big Bad) Wolf, who will be played in this incarnation by Johnny Depp. Yes, 50-year-old Johnny Depp is going to sing "Hello, Little Girl" ("Look at that flesh / pink and plump") to Sophia Grace.}}{{cite news|last=Strecker|first=Erin|title=Viral video star Sophia Grace Brownlee joins 'Into the Woods' as...|url=http://insidemovies.ew.com/2013/08/07/into-the-woods-sophia-grace-brownlee/|accessdate=September 5, 2013|newspaper=Entertainment Weekly|date=August 7, 2013}} Mauzy later revealed that she first auditioned for Cinderella but did not get the part. However, director Marshall saw her audition tape and brought her back in for Rapunzel, after recognizing "the 'vulnerability' and 'emotion' Mauzy could bring to Rapunzel after she read just one line", as he recalled.{{cite news|last1=Maresca|first1=Rachel|title=MacKenzie Mauzy scores 'dream' role of Rapunzel in Disney's 'Into the Woods' thanks to her hair|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/movies/mackenzie-mauzy-talks-landing-woods-rapunzel-role-article-1.2052314|accessdate=January 22, 2015|work=New York Daily News|date=December 20, 2014}} The film's plot synopsis and the official casting of lead actors Meryl Streep, Johnny Depp, Anna Kendrick, Chris Pine, and Emily Blunt were revealed at the [[D23 (Disney)|D23 Expo]] on August 10, 2013.{{cite news|last=Cerasaro|first=Pat|title=Complete Disney INTO THE WOODS Presentation At D23!|url=http://www.broadwayworld.com/bwwmovies/article/Complete-Disney-INTO-THE-WOODS-Presentation-At-D23-20130812|accessdate=September 7, 2013|newspaper=Broadway World|date=August 12, 2013}}{{cite news|last=Graser|first=Marc|title=D23 Expo: Disney Shows No Force But Plenty of Films|url=https://variety.com/2013/film/news/d23-expo-disney-shows-no-force-but-plenty-of-films-1200576759/|accessdate=September 5, 2013|newspaper=Variety|date=August 10, 2013}} On September 16, 2013, [[Lilla Crawford]] was confirmed as playing the character of Little Red Riding Hood, despite previous reports suggesting Brownlee. Crawford auditioned for Marshall via [[Skype]], who offered her the role within two hours; she was on a flight to London the next day. Later on, Dominic Brownlee spoke about the withdrawal of his daughter Sophia Grace from the movie: "After careful consideration, we the parents of Sophia Grace, felt that as rehearsals progressed that she was too young for this part. It was a joint decision between us and the director and producer of ''Into the Woods'' to withdraw Sophia Grace from the film."[http://www.broadwayworld.com/article/Sophia-Grace-INTO-THE-WOODS-Exit-Explained-Dad-Comments-20130917 Sophia Grace INTO THE WOODS Exit Explained; Dad Comments] Retrieved September 17, 2013 Apart from Crawford, the casting of Richard Glover, [[Frances de la Tour]], [[Simon Russell Beale]], [[Joanna Riding]], and [[Annette Crosbie]] in other roles was also separately announced later on September 16. ===Filming=== [[File:Keep and entrance of Dover Castle, 2007.jpg|thumb|[[Dover Castle]] in [[Kent]] was used as the exterior for the Prince's castle.]] In July 2013, before filming began, Marshall put the cast through six weeks of rehearsals on a soundstage and [[Blocking (stage)|blocked]] their scenes.{{cite news|last1=Burlingame|first1=Jon|title=Rob Marshall Boldly Explores Disney's Take on Twisted Tale 'Into the Woods'|url=https://variety.com/2014/film/features/into-the-woods-rob-marshall-disney-1201346785/|accessdate=January 7, 2015|work=Variety|publisher=Variety Media, LLC|date=November 4, 2014}} In August, the cast members visited [[Angel Recording Studios]] to separately record their respective parts in the presence of Sondheim himself. Over 90% of the vocal tracks in the final version of the film are from the recording studio sessions, while the rest were recorded on location or on the set. The advantage of blocking and rehearsing all scenes first was that the cast members could then precisely calibrate their voices in the recording studio to the planned appearance of each scene when later filmed, thereby minimizing the slightly disconcerting disconnection between vocals and choreography typical of [[music video]]s.{{cite news|last1=Marchant|first1=Beth|title=Editor Wyatt Smith Goes Into the Woods to Cut Sound, Picture and Song|url=http://www.studiodaily.com/2015/01/editor-wyatt-smith-goes-woods-cutting-sound-picture-song/|accessdate=January 9, 2015|work=StudioDaily|publisher=Access Intelligence|date=January 7, 2015}} Principal photography took place at London's [[Shepperton Studios]] in September 2013, with additional filming taking place at [[Dover Castle]], [[Hambleden]], [[Waverley Abbey]],{{cite web|author=Kent Film Office|url=http://kentfilmoffice.co.uk/2015/01/into-the-woods-2015/|title=Kent Film Office Into the Woods Article}}{{cite news|last=Verrier|first=Richard|title=Disney film 'Into the Woods' begins production in U.K.|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/envelope/cotown/la-et-ct-disney-into-the-woods20130916,0,5530147.story|accessdate=September 18, 2013|newspaper=The Los Angeles Times|date=September 16, 2013}}{{cite news|last=Cerasaro|first=Pat|title=INTO THE WOODS Movie Filming At Dover Castle Soon?|url=http://www.broadwayworld.com/article/INTO-THE-WOODS-Movie-Filming-At-Dover-Castle-Later-This-Month-20130906|accessdate=September 7, 2013|newspaper=Broadway World|date=September 6, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130910040020/http://www.broadwayworld.com/article/INTO-THE-WOODS-Movie-Filming-At-Dover-Castle-Later-This-Month-20130906|archive-date=September 10, 2013|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} and [[Richmond Park]].{{cite web | url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b03qflhm | title=Meryl Streep; Oscar Isaac; Sundance festival; National Trust film locations | publisher=[[BBC Radio 4]] | work=The Film Programme | accessdate=February 13, 2014}}{{cite news | title=Streep praises 'magical' park | work=Richmond and Twickenham Times | date=February 7, 2014 }} A forest of ancient [[pine]] trees in [[Windsor Great Park]] was used for many of the scenes in the woods.{{cite news|last1=McElroy|first1=Steven|title=One Day Your Prince Will Come (Whining)|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/12/28/movies/one-day-your-prince-will-come-whining-.html|accessdate=January 3, 2015|work=The New York Times|publisher=The New York Times Company|date=December 24, 2014|page=AR15}} Marshall struggled with how to stage the melodramatic duet "Agony" in the forest until discovering online that Windsor had an artificial waterfall at [[Virginia Water Lake]], which turned out to be the perfect location for the song. The production was shot digitally, using [[Arri Alexa]] cameras configured in a [[Multiple-camera setup|two-camera setup]]. Footage was edited together in [[Avid Technology|Avid]] [[Media Composer]]. The exterior of [[Byfleet Manor]] in Surrey served as Cinderella's home.http://www.smh.com.au/entertainment/into-the-woods/into-the-woods-the-journey-from-stage-to-screen-20150116-12rnwc.html The filmmakers spent a whole day shooting scenes which involved Rapunzel's hair being climbed upon. Mauzy claimed that the filmmakers wanted to take advantage of her blonde hair, and that the top of Rapunzel's hair appeared in the film was her own real hair; make-up artists only braided it into the extension. This hair extension was engineered by hair designer Peter King.{{cite news|last1=Novak|first1=Lexi|title=The Story of Rapunzel's Hair From Into the Woods|url=http://www.allure.com/beauty-trends/blogs/daily-beauty-reporter/2014/12/into-the-woods-rapunzel-hair.html|accessdate=January 22, 2015|work=[[Allure (magazine)|Allure]]|publisher=Condé Nast|date=December 23, 2014}} After testing loose, flowing hair which King found "uncontrollable", he decided to have twenty-seven wefts of real hair woven together into a 30-foot braid, a design which took inspiration from an Arthur Rackham illustration of Rapunzel. In order to bring in enough real Russian hair strands needed for the extension, King and his team had to work with several distributors from Germany and England. The hair-braiding process required three people, each holding a separate strand and weaving in and out. King also dyed the wefts for them to match Mauzy's champagne blonde hair color, and blended together six different shades from ash and strawberry to create realistic gradations and highlights. Between scenes, Mauzy had to "wrap [the hair] around her arm like huge rolls of wool", as recalled by King. A stuntman was employed to shoot hair-climbing scenes. Thin rope and metal rings were the only additional tools concealed within the braid to hold the weight of a person climbing up. The film's final shot, which essentially merges into and links back to its first shot, actually transitions digitally between three shots: a [[Technocrane]] on location lifting as high as possible into the sky, an [[Unmanned aerial vehicle|aerial drone]] flying down a valley in [[Wales]], and a shot of an overcast sky in [[Manhattan]], [[New York City]].{{cite news|last1=Failes|first1=Ian|title=Into the Woods: full of effects surprises|url=http://www.fxguide.com/featured/into-the-woods-full-of-effects-surprises/|accessdate=January 3, 2015|work=FXGuide|publisher=FXGuide.com, LLC|date=December 26, 2014}} Filming concluded on November 27, 2013.{{cite news|last=Cerasaro|first=Pat|title=Filming Wraps On INTO THE WOODS Movie! James Corden & More Tweet From Set|url=http://www.broadwayworld.com/article/Filming-Wraps-On-INTO-THE-WOODS-Movie-James-Corden-More-Tweet-From-Set-20131128|accessdate=November 28, 2013|newspaper=Broadway World|date=November 28, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140809003234/http://www.broadwayworld.com/article/Filming-Wraps-On-INTO-THE-WOODS-Movie-James-Corden-More-Tweet-From-Set-20131128|archive-date=August 9, 2014|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} On July 14, 2014, Steve Baldwin posted on a social networking site that reshoots were made during the whole month of July.{{cite news|last=Cerasaro|first=Pat|url=http://www.broadwayworld.com/article/INTO-THE-WOODS-Movie-Set-For-Month-Of-Reshoots-20140714|title=INTO THE WOODS Movie Set For Reshoots?|accessdate=July 31, 2014|newspaper=Broadway World|date=July 14, 2014}} The following month, however, Rob Marshall denied the film went through re-shoots. Instead, they spent three days [[Pick-up (filmmaking)|shooting new material]] that had been cut and re-added to the script after Disney screened the movie.{{cite news|last=Snetiker|first=Marc|url=http://insidemovies.ew.com/2014/08/14/into-the-woods-rob-marshall/|title='Into the Woods' director Rob Marshall answers all your burning questions|accessdate=August 14, 2014|newspaper=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|date=August 14, 2014}} For his role as the Wolf, Depp worked closely with the film's costume designer [[Colleen Atwood]] to create a [[Tex Avery]]-inspired costume, complete with [[zoot suit]] and [[fedora]].{{cite news|last1=Thilman|first1=James|title=Oscar Winning Costume Designer Colleen Atwood Vies For Yet Another Nomination|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/12/24/colleen-atwood-interview_n_6142646.html|accessdate=December 27, 2014|work=The Huffington Post|date=December 24, 2014}} ===Music=== {{main|Into the Woods (soundtrack)}} As noted above, the majority of the songs were pre-recorded by the cast. Music producer Mike Higham, who had previously worked with Sondheim on ''Sweeney Todd'': ''The Demon Barber of Fleet Street'', recorded the film's score with the [[London Symphony Orchestra]] and [[London Philharmonic Orchestra|London Philharmonic]]. Music supervisor and conductor [[Paul Gemignani]] instructed the actors on how to sing, including singing live to a camera on set, to prerecorded music in studio, and with a live studio orchestra. [[Jonathan Tunick]] orchestrated Sondheim's original music. The [[Key (music)|key]] to the song, "Hello, Little Girl," was altered to better suit [[Johnny Depp]]'s lower vocal range. In regards to the song's musical arrangement, Higham explained, "we emphasized the woodwinds to make it feel a little lighter, especially the flutes. And we just made it a little jazzier — played more on the walking bass line. Inherently, when it has a jazz feel, it just feels lighter."{{cite news|last1=Lee|first1=Ashley|title='Into the Woods': How Disney Tiptoed Around Johnny Depp's Creepy, Sexualized Song|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/woods-johnny-depp-sings-hello-760348|accessdate=December 27, 2014|work=The Hollywood Reporter|date=December 25, 2014}} The film's soundtrack was released by [[Walt Disney Records]] on December 15, 2014.{{cite web|title=Walt Disney Records Set To Release Into The Woods Original Motion Picture Soundtrack and Into The Woods Deluxe Edition On December 16th|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/walt-disney-records-set-to-release-into-the-woods-original-motion-picture-soundtrack-and-into-the-woods-deluxe-edition-on-december-16th-282182481.html|publisher=PRNewswire|accessdate=December 13, 2014|location=Burbank, California|format=Press release|date=November 10, 2014}} While it was initially reported that the film version would feature two new songs: a duet for the Baker and his Wife, titled "Rainbows"—originally written for a 1992 film adaptation that was never made—and a new song for the Witch, eventually titled "She'll Be Back".{{cite news|last=Johnson|first=Zack|title=Disney's Into the Woods Features Major Plot Changes, Stephen Sondheim Reveals—Spoilers Ahead!|url=http://www.eonline.com/news/552578/disney-s-into-the-woods-features-major-plot-changes-stephen-sondheim-reveals-spoilers-ahead|accessdate=June 19, 2014|newspaper=E! Online|date=June 19, 2014}} In the end, neither song appears in the finished film: "Rainbows" was cut before shooting began and "She'll Be Back", though filmed, was cut from the film on the grounds that it slowed the story down. "She'll Be Back" was included as a bonus feature on the film's home media release.Gioia, Michael. [http://www.playbill.com/news/article/title-of-meryl-streeps-cut-song-from-into-the-woods-revealed-334712 "Title of Meryl Streep's Cut Song from ''Into the Woods'' Revealed"] Playbill.com, November 4, 2014 ==Release== The first official company presentation took place at the 2013 [[Disney D23]] expo.{{cite news|url=http://www.broadwayworld.com/bwwmovies/article/Complete-Disney-INTO-THE-WOODS-Presentation-At-D23-20130812|title=Complete Disney INTO THE WOODS Presentation At D23!|work=Broadway World|date=August 12, 2013|accessdate=September 11, 2014|last1=Cerasero|first1=Pat}} The official teaser trailer debuted on July 31, 2014.{{cite news|url=http://insidemovies.ew.com/2014/07/31/into-the-woods-trailer/|title='Into the Woods' teaser trailer: No one sings, but everyone wishes|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|date=July 31, 2014|accessdate=July 31, 2014|last1=Snetiker|first1=Marc}}{{cite news|url=http://www.comingsoon.net/news/movienews.php?id=121271|title=Watch the First Trailer for Disney's Into the Woods!|work=comingsoon.net|date=July 31, 2014|accessdate=July 31, 2014}} A featurette was released showing behind-the-scenes clips and the vocals of Streep, Kendrick, Blunt and others.{{cite news|url=http://collider.com/into-the-woods-extended-featurette/|title=Extended INTO THE WOODS Featurette Provides Plenty of New Footage from the Upcoming Musical|work=Collider|date=October 23, 2014|accessdate=November 5, 2014}} A second trailer was released on November 6, 2014.{{cite news|url=http://insidemovies.ew.com/2014/11/06/new-into-the-woods-trailer-now-with-more-singing/|title=New 'Into the Woods' trailer: Now with more singing|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|date=November 6, 2014|accessdate=November 6, 2014|last1=Zuckerman|first1=Esther}} The film held its world premiere at the [[Ziegfeld Theatre (1969)|Ziegfeld Theatre]] in [[New York City]] on December 8, 2014.{{cite news|last1=Lee|first1=Ashley|title=Meryl Streep, Anna Kendrick Share the Many 'Into the Woods' Morals for Adult Moviegoers|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/woods-meryl-streep-anna-kendrick-755378|accessdate=December 10, 2014|work=The Hollywood Reporter|date=December 9, 2014}} It was released theatrically in the United States on December 25, 2014. ===Home media=== [[Walt Disney Studios Home Entertainment]] released the film on [[Blu-ray]], DVD, and digital download in North America on March 24, 2015.{{cite news|last=Murray|first=Noel|title='Into the Woods' leaps from musical theater to movie theaters|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/movies/la-et-mn-new-releases-into-the-woods-unbroken-20150322-story.html|accessdate=March 25, 2015|work=Los Angeles Times|date=March 21, 2015}} The film debuted in second place on the home media charts behind ''[[The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies]]''.{{cite news|last=Arnold|first=Thomas K.|title='Hobbit' Leads Pack of New Home Video Releases|url=https://variety.com/2015/film/news/hobbit-home-video-sales-1201464855/|accessdate=July 27, 2015|work=Variety|date=April 1, 2015}} The home media version includes Stephen Sondheim and James Lapine's original song "''She'll Be Back''".{{cite news|last=Robbins|first=Caryn|title=VIDEO: Meryl Streep Performs INTO THE WOODS Deleted Song 'She'll Be Back'!|url=http://www.broadwayworld.com/article/VIDEO-Meryl-Streep-Performs-INTO-THE-WOODS-Deleted-Song-Shell-Be-Back-20150227|accessdate=July 27, 2015|work=Broadway World|date=February 27, 2015}} ==Reception== ===Box office=== ''Into the Woods'' grossed $128 million in North America, and $85.1 million in other territories, for a worldwide total of $213.1 million, against a budget of $50 million. ''Into the Woods'' began playing across North American theaters on December 24, 2014, and earned $1.1 million from late-night [[Christmas Eve]] showings{{cite web | url = http://deadline.com/2014/12/christmas-box-office-into-the-woods-unbroken-the-interview-1201336253/ | title = Christmas Box Office: 'Into The Woods', 'Unbroken' Looking Bright | author = Anthony D'Alessandro | publisher = Deadline.com | date = December 25, 2014 | accessdate = December 26, 2014}}{{cite web | url = https://variety.com/2014/film/news/disneys-into-the-woods-starts-with-1-1-million-at-latenight-shows-1201387331/ | title = Disney's 'Into the Woods' Starts Strong with $1.1 Million at Latenight Shows | author = Dave McNary | publisher = ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' | date = December 25, 2014 | accessdate = December 26, 2014}} and $15.08 million on its opening day (including previews) from 2,440 theaters.{{cite web | url = http://deadline.com/2014/12/christmas-box-office-into-the-woods-unbroken-the-interview-1201336253/ | title = 'Unbroken' Leads But 'Into The Woods' Back In Race – Christmas B.O. Update | author = Anthony D'Alessandro and Brian Brooks | publisher = Deadlone.com | date = December 26, 2014 | accessdate = December 27, 2014}} Its opening day gross was the fourth-biggest [[Christmas Day]] debut and the sixth-biggest Christmas Day gross ever.{{cite web | url = https://www.forbes.com/sites/scottmendelson/2014/12/26/christmas-box-office-unbroken-into-the-woods-score-above-selma-american-sniper-score-below/ | title = Christmas Box Office: 'Unbroken,' 'Into The Woods' Score Above, 'Selma,' 'American Sniper' Score Below | author = Scott Mendelson | publisher = ''[[Forbes]]'' | date = December 26, 2014 | accessdate = December 27, 2014}} The film was among one of four films put into [[wide release]] on December 25, 2014, the other three being [[Universal Studios|Universal Pictures]]' ''[[Unbroken (film)|Unbroken]]'' (3,131 theaters), [[Paramount Pictures]]' ''[[The Gambler (2014 film)|The Gambler]]'' (2,478 theaters), and [[The Weinstein Company|TWC]]'s ''[[Big Eyes]]'' (1,307 theaters).{{cite web | url = https://www.forbes.com/sites/scottmendelson/2014/12/27/friday-box-office-jolies-unbroken-tops-into-the-woods-the-interview-drops-hard/ | title = Friday Box Office: Jolie's 'Unbroken' Tops 'Into The Woods,' 'The Interview' Drops Hard | author = Scott Mendelson | publisher = ''Forbes'' | date = December 27, 2014 | accessdate = December 28, 2014}} It earned $31.1 million in its traditional three-day opening ($46.1 million including its Christmas Day gross) debuting at #2 at the box office behind ''[[The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies]]'', achieving the highest opening weekend for a film based on a Broadway musical (previously held by ''[[Mamma Mia! (film)|Mamma Mia!]]'').{{cite web | url = http://www.broadwayworld.com/article/Official-Numbers-Now-In-INTO-THE-WOODS-2-At-Box-Office-Biggest-Movie-Musical-Opening-Ever-20141229 | title = Official Numbers Now In! INTO THE WOODS #2 At Box Office & Biggest Broadway Movie Musical Opening Ever | author = Pat Cerasaro| publisher = Broadway World | date = December 29, 2014 | accessdate = December 29, 2014}}{{cite news | title = "Into the Woods" Slides Into Second Place in Domestic Box-Office Totals, Beating "Unbroken" | authors=Michael Gioia, Vichet Chum | publisher = [[Playbill]] |quote=As previously reported, the Rob Marshall-directed film has become the biggest launch of a Broadway adaptation since "Mamma Mia!" ($27.8 million). | date = December 30, 2014 | url = http://www.playbill.com/news/article/into-the-woods-slides-into-second-place-in-domestic-box-office-totals-beating-unbroken-338152 | accessdate=January 5, 2012}} The film's $3.5 million debut in Japan marked the largest opening for a 21st-century [[live-action]] musical film.{{cite news|last1=Blair|first1=Gavin|title=Japan Box Office: 'Into the Woods' Has Best Opening for Live-Action Musical Since Millennium|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/japan-box-office-woods-has-781629|accessdate=March 30, 2015|work=The Hollywood Reporter|date=March 16, 2015}} ===Critical response=== The review aggregation website [[Rotten Tomatoes]] reports an approval rating of 71% based on 207 reviews, with an average rating of 6.6/10. The site's consensus reads: "On the whole, this Disney adaptation of the Sondheim classic sits comfortably at the corner of [[Hollywood]] and [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]]—even if it darkens to its detriment in the final act."{{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/into_the_woods_2014/|title=Into the Woods|date=December 25, 2014|work=Rotten Tomatoes|accessdate=September 12, 2018}} Another review aggregator, [[Metacritic]], calculate a weighted average score of 69 out of 100, based on 41 critics, indicating "generally favorable reviews".{{cite web | url=http://www.metacritic.com/movie/into-the-woods | title=Into the Woods Reviews | work=[[Metacritic]] | publisher=[[CBS Interactive]] | accessdate=January 8, 2015}} In [[CinemaScore]] polls conducted during the opening weekend, audiences gave the film an average grade of "B" on an A+ to F scale.{{cite web | url = http://www.boxofficemojo.com/news/?id=3987&p=.htm | title = Weekend Report (cont.): Huge Limited Debuts for 'American Sniper,' 'Selma' | author = Ray Subers | publisher = Box Office Mojo | date = December 28, 2014 | accessdate = December 29, 2014}} Streep was immensely applauded for her performance as the Witch, with many critics and audiences believing she was the film's heart. Lou Lumenick of the New York Post called her and Blunt's portrayals as "two of the greatest female performances of the year". For her performance, Streep received [[Academy Award]], [[Golden Globe Award]], [[Screen Actors Guild Award]], and [[Broadcast Film Critics Association Award]] nominations for Best Supporting Actress. ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'' wrote that the film "benefits from respect for the source material, enticing production values and a populous gallery of sharp character portraits from a delightful cast".{{cite news|last1=Rooney|first1=David|title='Into the Woods': Film Review|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/movie/woods/review/758611|accessdate=December 17, 2014|work=The Hollywood Reporter}} [[Stephen Holden]] of ''[[The New York Times]]'' lauded the film, writing; "''Into the Woods'', the splendid Disney screen adaptation of the Stephen Sondheim-James Lapine musical, infuses new vitality into the tired marketing concept of entertainment for 'children of all ages'".{{cite news|last1=Holden|first1=Stephen|title=The Quest for Storybook Endings in a Scary but Magical World|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/12/25/movies/into-the-woods-disneys-take-on-the-sondheim-lapine-classic.html|accessdate=December 25, 2014|work=The New York Times|date=December 24, 2014}} [[Leonard Maltin]] called the movie as "one of the year's best films". Similarly, Pete Hammond of Deadline praised the film as "the most dazzling movie musical since Marshall's own Chicago." and praised the performance of the cast, particularly Streep. Lou Lumerick of the New York Post called the film "this century's best musical" and lauded the performances of Streep and Blunt as the best female performances of the year. Scott Mendelson of ''[[Forbes]]'' gave a positive review declaring the film "Rob Marshall's best movie ever" and praised it for its genuine entertainment and strong cast performances.{{cite web | url = https://www.forbes.com/sites/scottmendelson/2014/12/19/review-disneys-into-the-woods-hits-a-sour-note/ | title = Review: Disney's 'Into The Woods' Hits A Sour Note | author = Scott Mendelson | publisher = ''Forbes'' | date = December 19, 2014 | accessdate = December 26, 2014}} [[Richard Corliss]] of [[Time (magazine)|''Time'']] gave a positive review, stating that the film was a "smart, appealing, upside-down children's story for adults of all ages".{{cite news|last1=Corliss|first1=Richard|title=REVIEW: Into the Woods: A Disney Musical for Adults of All Ages|url=http://time.com/3647510/review-into-the-woods-a-disney-musical-for-adults-of-all-ages/|accessdate=December 27, 2014|work=Time|date=December 27, 2014}} Gregory Ellwood of [[HitFix]] tipped Streep as an [[Academy Awards|Academy Award]] contender in the [[Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress|Best Supporting Actress]] category, and also praised the performance of Chris Pine.{{cite web| url = http://www.hitfix.com/in-contention/can-meryl-streep-actually-win-a-fourth-oscar-for-into-the-woods| title = Can Meryl Streep Actually Win A Fourth Oscar For Into The Woods?| author = Gregory Ellwood| date = November 23, 2014| accessdate = December 16, 2014| publisher = Hitfix.com}} Richard Lawson of ''[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]]'',{{cite news|last1=Lawson|first1=Richard|title=Into the Woods Is a Fairy-Tale Musical Without Much Magic|url=http://www.vanityfair.com/vf-hollywood/2014/12/into-the-woods-review|accessdate=January 3, 2015|work=Vanity Fair|publisher=Conde Nast|date=December 24, 2014}} Karen D'Souza of the ''[[San Jose Mercury News]]'',{{cite news|last1=D'Souza|first1=Karen|title=Review: 'Into the Woods' impressive, but a bit too tame|url=http://www.mercurynews.com/entertainment/ci_27165386/review-into-woods-impressive-but-bit-too-tame?source=rss|accessdate=January 3, 2015|work=San Jose Mercury News|publisher=Bay Area News Group|date=December 18, 2014}} and [[Dana Stevens (critic)|Dana Stevens]] of ''[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]''{{cite news|last1=Stevens|first1=Dana|title=Into the Woods|url=http://www.slate.com/articles/arts/movies/2014/12/into_the_woods_starring_meryl_streep_and_emily_blunt_reviewed.html|accessdate=January 3, 2015|work=Slate|publisher=The Slate Group|date=December 24, 2014}} all published critical reviews of the film. All three found much to like in the acting (especially Blunt and Pine's performances), but all three also concluded that after the various cuts and changes, the final version of the film had failed to adequately preserve the power of the dark [[Existentialism|existentialist]] message at the heart of the original musical's second act. Stevens characterized the result as a "generic [[dystopia]]n bummer," while Lawson criticized the film as a "dutiful but perfunctory adaptation" which lacked "genuine heart". Paul Katz of ''[[The Huffington Post]]'' felt the change in tone between the last two acts was too abrupt, and also criticized the film's faithfulness to the stage musical.{{cite news|last1=Katz|first1=Paul|title=Into the Woods (Review)|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/paul-katz/into-the-woods-review_1_b_6381348.html|accessdate=March 19, 2015|work=The Huffington Post|date=December 29, 2014}} Conversely, Alyssa Rosenberg of ''[[The Washington Post]]'' disliked the performances by Streep and Depp, while simultaneously calling the film's first two acts a "surprising delight".{{cite news|last1=Rosenberg|first1=Alyssa|title=How Disney wrecked "Into The Woods"|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/act-four/wp/2014/12/26/how-disney-wrecked-into-the-woods/|accessdate=March 19, 2015|work=The Washington Post|date=December 26, 2014}} ===Accolades=== {| class="wikitable sortable" width="99%" |- style="background:#ccc; text-align:center;" ! colspan="5" style="background: LightSteelBlue;" | List of awards and nominations |- style="background:#ccc; text-align:center;" ! revision.text:
{{Infobox artist | name = Irina Ivanovna Getmanskaya | image = | imagesize = 200px | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1939|1|6|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Leningrad]], USSR | death_date = | death_place = | field = Painting | citizenship = USSR, [[Russian Federation]] | nationality = Russian | training = [[Repin Institute of Arts]] | movement = [[Realism (visual art)|Realism]] | works = | patrons = | awards = }}
'''Irina Ivanovna Getmanskaya''' ({{lang-ru|Ири́на Ива́новна Ге́тманская}}; born 6 January 1939, Leningrad, USSR) is a Soviet, Russians painter and art teacher, living and working in [[Saint Petersburg]], a member of the [[Saint Petersburg Union of Artists]] (before 1992 named as the Leningrad branch of Union of Artists of Russian Federation),<ref>''Directory of Members of the Union of Artists of USSR. Volume 2.''- Moscow: Soviet artist, 1979. - p.405.</ref> regarded as a representative of the Leningrad school of painting.<ref>''Sergei V. Ivanov. Unknown Socialist Realism. The Leningrad School.''- Saint Petersburg: NP-Print Edition, 2007. – pp.183, 359, 395, 396.</ref>
== Biography == Getmanskaya (born '''Sysoeva''') was born on 6 January 1939, in Leningrad, USSR, to an artistic family. From 1950 to 1957 she studied in the [[Leningrad Secondary Art School]] under the All-Union Academy of Arts. She was a student of Alexei Kuznetsov and Alexander Bulygin.
In 1959 she entered the Department of Painting of the [[Repin Institute of Arts|Leningrad Institute of Painting, Sculpture and Architecture named after Ilya Repin]]. She studied with Alexander Debler, Boris Ugarov, Viktor Reykhet, Vitaly Valtsev, and Vladislav Anisovich.
In 1964 she graduated from [[Repin Institute of Arts|Ilya Repin Institute]] at the Victor Oreshnikov studio. Her graduation work was the painting "A Portrait of Sculpture", dedicated to the memory of her father, who died in the blockade of Leningrad.<ref>''Anniversary Directory graduates of Saint Petersburg State Academic Institute of Painting, Sculpture, and Architecture named after Ilya Repin, Russian Academy of Arts. 1915 - 2005''. - Saint Petersburg: Pervotsvet Publishing House, 2007. p.94.</ref>
Irina Getmanskaya has participated in Art Exhibitions Since 1965. She painted portraits, landscapes, genre compositions, worked as painter of the Leningrad department of Art Found of Russian Federation.
Between 1960 and 1970 Irina Getmanskaya traveled much to [[Ural (region)|Ural Province]]{{Clarify|date=September 2011}}<!-- no such geographic entity -->, [[Murmansk]] and [[Kandalaksha]], [[Krasnoyarsk]] and [[Middle Asia]]. She worked also at the Houses of artistic creation "Acedemicheskaya Dacha" (Tver region), and "Hot Key" (North Caucasus).
Irina Getmanskaya is most famous for her contemporary portraits. Her style developed from the naturalist painting of 1960 in the direction of more decorative color and generalized composition while maintaining a constructive style of drawing.
Irina Getmanskaya is a Member of [[Saint Petersburg Union of Artists]] (before 1992 [[Leningrad branch of Union of Artists of Russian Federation]]) since 1975.<ref>''Directory of members of the Leningrad branch of Union of Artists of Russian Federation''. - Leningrad: Khudozhnik RSFSR, 1987. - p.30.</ref>
In 1967-1975 Getmanskaya taught at the [[Vera Mukhina Institute|Leningrad Higher School of Industrial Art named after Vera Mukhina]]. Paintings by Irina Getmanskaya reside in Art museums and private collections in Russia, France, Germany, in the U.S., England and other countries.
==References== {{reflist}}
== Bibliography == * ''Matthew C. Bown. Dictionary of 20th Century Russian and Soviet Painters 1900-1980s''. - London: Izomar, 1998. {{ISBN|0-9532061-0-6}}, {{ISBN|978-0-9532061-0-0}}. * ''Sergei V. Ivanov. Unknown Socialist Realism. The Leningrad School.'' - Saint Petersburg: NP-Print Edition, 2007. – pp. 183, 359, 395, 396. {{ISBN|5-901724-21-6}}, {{ISBN|978-5-901724-21-7}}.

Ivanov. The Leningrad School of painting. Historical outline.''] * [http://www.leningradartist.com/chronology.htm ''Chronology of the Leningrad School of painting. ''] * [http://www.leningradartist.com/ ''Unknown Socialist Realism. Quests and Discoveries''.]
{{Fine Art of Leningrad |state=autocollapse}}
